reasoning:
First things first, Nvidia sits well outside my circle of competence. Semiconductors and rapid hardware cycles are like trying to predict the weather – ever-changing and full of surprises. I’ve stuck to businesses I understand: consumer staples, insurance, railroads, and the occasional tech exception in Apple’s case, where I see a simple consumer ecosystem and switching costs.

On the moat front, it’s a mixed bag. Those sky-high operating margins (65%) hint at pricing power, but cyclicality and only one out of ten years with ROE north of 15% show an inconsistent fortress. A durable moat? I’m skeptical.

Management has put up decent results, yet recent share issuances dilute owners and they pay virtually no dividend. I want managers who act like owners; issuing stock to fuel growth isn’t always a bad sign, but it’s not a hallmark of frugal capital allocation either.

Financially, Nvidia scores okay on debt and margins, but the earnings picture is inconsistent – zero points on consistency. Manufacturing in this industry is capital-intensive and earnings swings can be brutal. That’s a risk I don’t relish.

Valuation is the clincher: my three-stage DCF pegs a conservative intrinsic value around $14,550 per share, yet the stock trades almost nine times that, leaving a negative margin of safety near 90%. As I always say, “Price is what you pay, value is what you get,” and this price leaves your wallet a lot lighter than the business is worth.

Long term? Technology pivots quickly. Today’s leader can be tomorrow’s footnote. When I compare this to owning Coca-Cola or Apple – businesses with steady cash flows, brands you see on Main Street, and moats you could drive a truck through – Nvidia doesn’t measure up for Berkshire.

In my book, I’d rather pass than risk permanent capital with scant margin for safety in a business I don’t fully understand.

fundamental_analysis.details: Weak ROE of 12.5%; Conservative debt levels; Strong operating margins; Current ratio data not available

consistency_analysis.details: Inconsistent earnings growth pattern; Total earnings growth of 429.3% over past 10 periods

moat_analysis.details: Inconsistent ROE: only 1/10 periods >15%; Strong and stable operating margins (avg: 62.5%) indicate pricing power moat; High performance stability (82.1%) suggests strong competitive moat

book_value_analysis.details: Good book value per share growth pattern

management_analysis.details: Recent common stock issuance (potential dilution); No or minimal dividends paid

details: Using three-stage DCF: Stage 1 (8.0%, 5y), Stage 2 (4.0%, 5y), Terminal (2.5%)
